metadata: whyHaHas for jokes in the whyHaHa collection

jokes.joke: Where do generals keep their armies? In their sleevies!
jokes.whyHaHa: A pun playing on the similar pronunciation of 'armies' and 'sleevies' (sleeves).

jokes.joke: I'm thinking of reasons to go to Switzerland. The flag is a big plus.
jokes.whyHaHa: A play on words where 'plus' has a double meaning: as an advantage and as the Swiss flag. The joke takes a literal interpretation of 'plus' in the context of Switzerland.

jokes.joke: I didn't like my beard at first. Then it grew on me.
jokes.whyHaHa: A clever play on words with the phrase 'grew on me', having two meanings: the literal growth of the beard and the figurative meaning of becoming fond of something over time.

jokes.joke: Why don't you starve in the desert? Because of the sand which is there.
jokes.whyHaHa: A non sequitur joke with an intentionally nonsensical punchline. The humor comes from the absurdity of suggesting sand as a reason for not starving. This is peak comedy btw.

jokes.joke: Why can't a bicycle stand on its own? It's two-tired.
jokes.whyHaHa: A classic pun playing on the homophone 'tired'. 'Two-tired' sounds like 'too tired' while also describing a bicycle's two wheels.

jokes.joke: Found out I was color blind the other day. That one came right out of the orange.
jokes.whyHaHa: A play on the double meaning of 'came out of the orange': literally referring to the color orange, while figuratively playing on the phrase 'came out of the blue' meaning something unexpected.

jokes.joke: A burger walks into a bar. The bartender says 'Sorry, we don't serve food here'
jokes.whyHaHa: A classic setup for a joke where the punchline comes from the unexpected literal interpretation of 'we don't serve food' when a food item (burger) is the one asking.

jokes.joke: What's more amazing than a talking dog? A spelling bee.
jokes.whyHaHa: A play on words where 'spelling bee' is both a type of insect and a competition for spelling. The joke works because bees can't talk, but they can spell (their name).

jokes.joke: Orion's Belt is a huge waist of space.
jokes.whyHaHa: A pun on the constellation Orion's Belt, where 'waist' is a play on words with 'waste', making a humorous connection between the celestial belt and a person's waistline.
A play on the phrase '7 ate 9' (7 ate 9), which sounds like '7, 8, 9' when spoken quickly.

jokes.joke: There are only 10 types of people in the world: those who understand binary, and those who don't.
